Mental Health Tips & Common Issues

Practical tips to support wellbeing and brief descriptions of common mental health issues with simple steps you can take. If you are in immediate danger or crisis, contact local emergency services or a crisis hotline right away.

Anxiety

Worry, restlessness, racing thoughts, or physical symptoms (racing heart, sweating).

Try: breathing exercises, limiting caffeine, short grounding techniques, and talking to someone you trust.

Depression

Persistent low mood, loss of interest, low energy, or changes in sleep/appetite.

Try: small daily activities, maintain social contact, and consider professional assessment if symptoms persist.

Stress & Burnout

Chronic overwhelm, exhaustion, irritability, and reduced performance.

Try: set boundaries, schedule breaks, delegate tasks, and practice relaxation (headspace, short walks).

Sleep Problems

Difficulty falling or staying asleep can worsen mood and concentration.

Try: consistent sleep schedule, reduce screens before bed, limit naps, and create a calming bedtime routine.

Social Isolation

Feeling lonely or disconnected can affect mental and physical health.

Try: small social goals (message one person a day), join local groups, or use online peer-support communities.

Mindfulness

Mindfulness helps you stay present, reduce stress, and respond to thoughts and feelings with greater calm and clarity.

Try: a 2‑minute focused breathing exercise, the 5‑4‑3‑2‑1 grounding technique, a brief body scan, or a mindful walk — start small and be consistent.

When to Seek Professional Help

If symptoms are severe, persistent, or interfere with daily life (work, relationships, sleep, safety), reach out to a mental health professional, your primary care provider, or local services. If you or someone else is at immediate risk, call emergency services or your local crisis line.

Positive Affirmations

Affirmations can help challenge and control negative thoughts or self-doubt.
